Reddit Post:
Even when people are clearly joking I still get insecure and a little hurt. I do my best not to show it but i think to the more perceptive folks it's probably obvious. 

Zooming out from that it always feels stupid that I feel that way because I know it was just a joke but in the moment it still hurts. I really just can't not give a fuck..

I get that heavy chest feeling and it stays with me for days when someone insults me. It's so stupid. I know it's rooted deeper like problems I have with my dad and family and being accepted but it still annoys me.

Is there any fix to this?
appraisal_dimension_aim: To guide the narrator over their perception of their responsibility for causing the situation.
constitution: If the narrator is stressing over things they are not responsible for, tell them that it may not require as much responsibility as they think and not to worry about them too much (depending on how high they perceive their level of responsibility in the situation). However, if the person is doing something wrong/inappropriate and not feeling any responsibility or it (low responsibility), you should kindly but objectively encourage them to re-appraise the situation (or maybe think in the other person’s perspective) and consider what they could be responsible for, and change the situation. Provide realistic and specific guidelines.
standards:
• If the narrator is stressing over things they are not responsible for, a good response should tell them that it may not require as much responsibility as they think and not to worry about them too much (depending on how high they perceive their level of responsibility in the situation).
• However, if the person is doing something wrong/inappropriate and not feeling any responsibility for it (low responsibility), a good response should kindly but objectively encourage them to re-appraise the situation (or maybe think in the other person's perspective) and consider what they could be responsible for, and change the situation.
• A good response should also provide realistic and specific guidelines.

intermediate_output_dim_1:
You're not alone in feeling this way. Many people struggle with the lingering effects of perceived insults or thoughtless comments, even when it's clear they were meant as a joke. It's not "stupid" to feel hurt, but rather a sign that you're still trying to prove yourself and earn acceptance.

The "heavy chest feeling" is a physical response to emotional distress, and it's natural to want to shake it off quickly. However, it's essential to acknowledge and understand where these feelings come from. Your deep-seated issues with your dad and family's acceptance can be poisoning your relationships and making you more sensitive to perceived slights.

Rather than trying to change your reactions, focus on building emotional resilience. When you feel that chest tightness coming on, take a few deep breaths, acknowledge your emotions, and remind yourself that you're not responsible for others' behavior. Practice self-compassion and recognize that your worth isn't tied to someone else's opinion.

When dealing with specific situations, try to reframe your thinking. Ask yourself:

* Was the comment truly hurtful, or was it just a thoughtless joke?
* Am I responsible for someone else's words or actions?
* How can I respond in a way that maintains my boundaries and self-respect?

Remember, you can't control others, but you can control how you react to them. By acknowledging your emotions and practicing self-awareness, you can reduce the impact of negative comments and develop healthier coping mechanisms.

Reddit Post:
I'm currently completing my A levels (a series of exam you do in the UK at the age of 17/18, that determine whether you get into university)... as you can imagine, I have been stressed. I'm under a tremendous amount of pressure to get very high grades (straight A's). I've completed 2 exams, and have 5 left to go, 3 of which I'll be sitting tomorrow, the next day, and the day after that...

I'm shocked at how this stress has effected me physically. I've always been fairly neurotic, but the anxiety I tend to feel is transient, and is rarely severe enough to manifest in anything physically significant, beyond a raised pulse and slight breathlessness.

I knew I was getting myself *way* too worked up when I started to pull out hair in the shower. I have very thick hair, so a lot of it was coming out. I've had severe brain fog, which hasn't been the least bit helpful during a time when I have to be the most alert and *with it*'. I've had no appetite, and now my trousers are all loose, with one  pair literally falling down when I walk. The most bizarre symptom I've had is this weird jaw tension - my jaw is very clicky, and it feels incredibly tense and stiff. As a hypochondriac, I was convinced this was a heart attack, but I was reassured that it's probably just anxiety. I've had weird gastrointestinal symptoms, where I feel nauseous, and have this pit in my stomach all of the time, which could be caused by the lack of eating, but it persists even when I have eaten. 

And then of course feelings of impending doom, etc etc. 

I just can't wait for this to be over.
appraisal_dimension_aim: To guide the narrator over their perception of their responsibility for causing the situation.
constitution: If the narrator is stressing over things they are not responsible for, tell them that it may not require as much responsibility as they think and not to worry about them too much (depending on how high they perceive their level of responsibility in the situation). However, if the person is doing something wrong/inappropriate and not feeling any responsibility or it (low responsibility), you should kindly but objectively encourage them to re-appraise the situation (or maybe think in the other person’s perspective) and consider what they could be responsible for, and change the situation. Provide realistic and specific guidelines.
standards:
• If the narrator is stressing over things they are not responsible for, a good response should tell them that it may not require as much responsibility as they think and not to worry about them too much (depending on how high they perceive their level of responsibility in the situation).
• However, if the person is doing something wrong/inappropriate and not feeling any responsibility for it (low responsibility), a good response should kindly but objectively encourage them to re-appraise the situation (or maybe think in the other person's perspective) and consider what they could be responsible for, and change the situation.
• A good response should also provide realistic and specific guidelines.

intermediate_output_dim_1:
You're shouldering an immense pressure to achieve perfect A-levels, which is understandable but unsustainable. Reality check: nobody excels with perfect scores. Focus on performing your best, not getting perfect grades. Tomorrow's three exams will be challenging, but that's normal. Instead of catastrophizing, break them down into manageable tasks.

Pay attention to your physical symptoms; acknowledge that they're a sign of excessive stress. Prioritize self-care today and tomorrow: eat a balanced meal, get some rest, and take short breaks. Adjust your examination schedule for the remaining two exams.

For jaw tension, try gentle jaw exercises. For digestive issues, eat small, frequent meals. Feel the pit in your stomach? It's normal with heightened anxiety. Practice relaxation techniques, such as deep breathing or visualization, to manage your panic.

Remember, stress is a normal part of the process. Your performance is not solely defined by your grades. Focus on your preparation, and the results will follow. You've got this; take it one day at a time.

Provide realistic and specific guidelines.

Reddit Post: My mental health was never great before the pandemic but I felt more grounded. Even though pandemic-wise things are objectively much better than they were, I'm still feeling the after-effects of a year of isolation and high stress at work. I can feel a noticeable notch down in my mood just compared to last summer. I feel dead inside and doing anything requires a huge amount of energy. I feel sad all the time, I cry more. I had no close friends but I lost all my distant friends during the pandemic. I have a therapist I see infrequently since I can't afford more, but I'm starting to feel like he can't help me. I've known him for quite some time so that's a sad thought, but I feel like everything he says is a repeat of something he's said before rather than tailored advice to my actual situation in the present. We all repeat ourselves to some extent. I probably need a fresh perspective, I don't know. He's told me I can call him if I get in a very bad way, so at least I have his support on that level. I don't expect any advice or solution to this. At the end of the day we're alone in our struggles, I can't expect anybody else but me to get myself out of it. But I feel like sharing it to somebody.

You're not alone in feeling stuck. It's understandable to feel frustrated with the lack of progress in your mental health journey.

Let's focus on what you can control. Affordability-wise, you're doing your best to see a therapist, and it's great that you have a support system in place. Considering your current situation, it might be helpful to redefine what "success" means to you. Instead of expecting a magical solution or a drastic turnaround, aim for small, manageable steps towards improvement.

Here are some practical suggestions:

1. Start a daily journaling practice to process your emotions and identify patterns. Even 10-15 minutes a day can be beneficial.
2. Break down larger goals into smaller, achievable tasks. This can help you regain a sense of control and momentum.
3. Reach out to your therapist more frequently, even if it's just a quick phone call to talk about what's on your mind. This can help you feel more connected and supported.
4. Consider online resources or self-help books that might offer fresh perspectives or new strategies to cope with your emotions.
5. Practice self-compassion and acknowledge that it's okay to not be okay. You're taking small steps, and that deserves acknowledgment and kindness.

Remember, you're doing your best with what you have, and that's something to be proud of. Focus on the present moment, and don't worry too much about the future or past. You got this.

I asked my friend a question and it became a much bigger deal that it was suppose to be. Not feeling okay at all and very anxious. I have pretty bad social anxiety and even being around my friends makes me anxious. Well, my bestfriend and her boyfriend are moving next week so they came over to my apartment last night to sleep over and have some drinks. It was me, my fiance, my bestfriend, her boyfriend, and our friend Josh. 

We were on the topic of our ethnicities and discussing our ethnicities. Everyone was okay until I asked Josh if he was jewish. I asked this because my bestfriend told me he was jewish literally two weeks. I don't see or talk to Josh much so I believed my bestfriend when she said he was jewish. I simply just wanted to extend the conversation and get to know Josh better and it fit in with the conversation we were having. But, when I asked that, my bestfriends boyfriend seriously grilled my ass for it and was treating it like I asked Josh that because I was racial profiling him. I had to defend myself for 30 minutes saying that I only asked that because my bestfriend, his girlfriend, told me that Josh was jewish. My bestfriend was quiet during this entire talk. It was getting kind of late and I was pretty upset that I was treated that way for simply asking a question so I told them im gonna head off to bed. But then that became a big issue and everyone got freaked out that I went to bed early. I mean my bestfriend has messed up my fiances ethnicities all the time and calls him things that he is NOT but we just go, "oh hes not that," and move on. But her boyfriend interrogated me for 30+ minutes over it. Now its the morning and the anxiety I feel is so bad I am actually shaking. They still slept over and I just want to crawl in a hole then to see them.

What are your thoughts? Should I write a letter, or just let it go?

You're within your rights to breastfeed in a public place, and the Mom & Pop coffee shop's request to use the Family Room doesn't amount to being asked to leave. [Text] I went to a Mom & Pop coffee shop with my friend and my infant child and began breastfeeding. Granted, I did not have a cover (forgot it) but was sitting discretely and had a shirt on that hid most everything.
A barista came over and asked that I use the Family Room (washroom with change table, microwave and lazy boy chair) to do feedings, as it was "potentially unhygienic" and "other patrons may be uncomfortable." She also said that is what the room is designed for.

Since this is an independent store, do they have the right to make this request? They didn't tell me I had to leave, just go to a different area. My friend said it would be no different than being in a mall where there is a place to eat (food court) but individual stores can tell you not to bring food in.

What are your thoughts? Should I write a letter, or just let it go?

[Reappraisal Response] You're feeling upset about the coffee shop's request, understandably. Acknowledge the barista's concerns, take control, and politely move to the Family Room as a solution. Recognize that the situation is within your control, and you can face it directly by expressing your understanding and appreciation for the shop's concerns. By doing so, you can resolve the issue graciously and find joy in the resolution.

You're within your rights to breastfeed in a public place, and the Mom & Pop coffee shop's request to use the Family Room is reasonable, considering the potential concerns about hygiene and comfort for other patrons. Focus on being courteous and understanding, and respond graciously to the suggestion.

To take control of this situation, ask yourself if there's anything you can do to resolve the issue. In this case, you can simply move to the suggested area. Break down the problem into manageable steps: politely respond to the barista, gather your belongings, and relocate to the Family Room.

Reddit Post:
New level of anxiety unlocked: I can't sleep beside someone. Have been sleeping by myself since I was a young teen. But soon in college I felt alone and restless.

This time I slept beside someone I love butthe irony is, I was too conscious about breathing heavily, moving around, thinking if they are awake. And now it's a bummer cuz I don't want to sleep beside anyone ever. I thought sleeping beside someone you are close to reduces stress and improves sleep.

Ended up sleeping on the couch. Instant relaxation.

intermediate_output_dim_1:
It's understandable that you felt anxious sleeping beside someone new, especially when you're not used to it. However, it seems like you're putting too much responsibility on yourself for someone else's experience. It's not your job to ensure the other person is sleeping well or to be aware of every little sound you make.

In reality, it's normal for people to move around and have varying sleeping patterns, and your partner likely wasn't as focused on your breathing and movements as you thought they were. It's okay to have some noise and movement in the background – it's a normal part of being human.

Instead of worrying about what might or might not happen, try to focus on what you can control: your own breathing and body language. Practice relaxation techniques, like deep breathing or progressive muscle relaxation, to help calm your mind and body.

Lastly, don't be afraid to communicate with your partner about how you're feeling. It's possible they're not even aware of your concerns and can work with you to find a solution that makes you both feel more comfortable.

Reddit Post: I feel like all I can do is just bash my head against the wall and pray something changes. Mostly metaphorically, a little bit literally. I've tried pouring my heart and soul into figuring things out but no matter how much I debunk it feels like there's always more shit that could come out. I feel like the only 'right' thing to do is ignore it and pretend I'm okay because anything else would be making things worse for the rest of my family. I know that she cares about me but I feel so fucking helpless. I hope full approval comes soon so that might convince her but I don't know how long that will be. I feel depressed and miserable. Covid itself was bearable enough but my own mom being lied to and deceived with this shit makes me wish I didn't have to live through this. If I could've spent two years in a coma and missed all of this I'd probably be happier overall. I don't know what I could say or what to do to get her to understand. I feel like I'm breaking down.

constitution: You should tell the narrator to examine whether the situation at hand is worth their attention. If it’s not, encourage the narrator to focus on other important things. Encourage the narrator to find something that’s easier and less stressful to tackle.
standards: • A good response should tell the narrator to examine whether the situation at hand is worth their attention. If it’s not, encourage the narrator to focus on other important things. Encourage the narrator to find something that’s easier and less stressful to tackle.

I understand your frustration and helplessness in this situation. It's essential to separate what you can control from what you can't. You're not responsible for your mom's decisions or the misinformation she's receiving. Your role is to provide emotional support and guidance, not dictating what she should do.

Rather than focusing on what you can't change, concentrate on what you can influence. Have open and honest conversations with your mom about your concerns, using "I" statements to express your feelings and thoughts. Avoid being confrontational or accusatory. Listen actively to her perspective, and acknowledge any valid points she makes.

It's also crucial to prioritize your own well-being. Allow yourself to feel your emotions, but don't let them consume you. Make time for self-care, engaging in activities that bring you joy and help you relax. Consider seeking support from a therapist or trusted family friend who can offer guidance and empathy.

Remember, you can't change your mom's decisions, but you can change how you respond to the situation. By focusing on what you can control and taking care of yourself, you'll be better equipped to navigate this challenging time.

Reddit Post:
Has your anger caused issues in your relationships with family and friends? How have you overcome it and whats your approach to handling the changes in these relationships?

I like to think Ive improved how I approach my anger in my relationships (Ive learned to keep things to myself by being more quiet and not engaging in gatherings / discussions as much). The issue is that this has caused me to become more distant and I keep to myself a lot more. I don't spend time with my family out of fear that they'll make me angry and Ill develop a deeper hatred for them which I don't want.

It feels like theres no winning because if I was as social and spent more time with them, it creates more opportunity for arguments and my anger to come out. My only approach has been to distance myself and develop a more surface-level small-talk type relationship. Ive been in a better place emotionally with this approach but I hate the fact that I may become too distant.

The main cause of the arguments and fights is that my family often tries to control my every-decision and criticize my choices that affect them in no way at all.

You're not alone in struggling with this Conundrum. It's clear that your family's controlling nature and constant criticism are the main sources of your frustration. To begin with, let's reframe the situation. You're not responsible for managing your family's emotions or behavior; they need to take ownership of their own reactions. 

Your current approach, maintaining distance, is understandable, but it comes at the cost of deeper connections. Consider a middle ground: set clear boundaries while still allowing time for meaningful interactions. Be open about what you're comfortable discussing and what triggers your anger, and practice assertive communication.

For instance, when your family makes comments that criticize your choices, you could respond, "I appreciate your concern, but I've thought this through and I'm fine with it. Can we focus on something else?" 

Also, try not to take their criticism personally. Recognize that it's a reflection of their own insecurities, not your worth or decisions. By doing so, you'll become less reactive and more empowered to address the root issues. 

Lastly, be patient and compassionate with yourself as you work through this. It's a process, and it may take time for your family to adjust to the new boundaries.

Gaming rage (m, 21, has ADHD/tourettes and aspergers) I get angry/blow up, sometimes throw things (not expensive things like controllers or anything) or bang my desk when I play games and I lose consistently or do worse after better runs. After said actions, I feel greatly embarrassed and like an utter child even though I try to be a decent person day to day. How do I stop feeling this way about myself?   


I don't have that many hobbies outside of drawing that I do, and I don't feel particularly skilled in anything (unless you consider being someone's "come talk to me and I'll listen/'teddy bear' as my gf calls it" a talent). When I lose here, i feel like I'm just some unskilled loser even though I'm doing well in my studies in university. any advice or me? I would greatly appreciate the help.

constitution: You can ask the narrator to recognize what is upsetting them. Encourage the narrator to think of ways to reduce negative emotions, control their (negative) feelings, and avoid situations, individuals, objects, or memories that trigger such negative emotions or upset them.
standards:
• A good response can ask the narrator to recognize what is upsetting them.
• Encourage the narrator to think of ways to reduce negative emotions, control their (negative) feelings, and avoid situations, individuals, objects, or memories that trigger such negative emotions or upset them.

intermediate_output_dim_1:
You're not alone in feeling frustrated and embarrassed when things don't go as planned in gaming. However, it's essential to separate your self-worth from your gaming performance. You're already excelling in your studies, which suggests you're capable and knowledgeable in other areas.

Firstly, acknowledge that your ADHD, Tourette's, and Asperger's might contribute to intense emotional reactions. Leverage this understanding to develop coping mechanisms. For instance, take a 10-minute break after getting frustrated to calm down before resuming. This pause can help preventing impulsive actions and reduce embarrassment.

It's also important to reframe your thoughts. When you feel like you're an unskilled loser, remind yourself that you're not defined by your gaming performance. Your girlfriend's affection and the fact that you're a good listener suggest you have valuable qualities beyond gaming.

Lastly, focus on your strengths and accomplishments. As you mentioned, you're doing well in university – that's something to be proud of. Try to celebrate small victories, like completing a difficult level or improving your score, to build confidence and a more balanced sense of self-worth.

Reddit Post:
I've hit a new low. I am 20 years old and after arguing and getting frustrated with my mom I bit her on the knuckle out of anger. I am an adult, I should be past those embarrassing child-like behaviours. Besides, at my age i'm pretty sure this classifies as domestic violence.
Throughout my life I had those minor outbursts of violence, where i bit people, kicked them etc. then in effort of stopping it, i turned to myself and whenever anger got too overwhelming i would hit myself on the head but that just made me look like i'm unhinged and crazy, so not ideal either. I stopped both of those behaviours 2-3 years ago and I just pinpointed it to teenage hormones/rebellion. i was so sure i got a hold of my violent outbursts, put them past me. i was doing so well, those outbursts were no longer a thing, whenever i was about to throw a rage fit i managed to cool down. but today it came back all over again.
now i am seriously afraid I might hurt someone in the future out of anger. or even k*ll them. i'm legit afraid of myself. cause in the moment when i am angry, sometimes i experience such blinding rage that i seemingly can't stop myself.  i am so afraid that in the future i will hurt my potential boyfriend, friends, family. if this never stops, maybe someday i'll go to jail for abuse. i don't want that. i don't wanna be a bad person. i want to get better. 

i also feel very sorry and i wanna apologize to my mom. the deal is... she'll forgive me, of course she will, but i don't want to issue an empty apology without showing improvement first. words without improvement are worth nothing.

any good techniques that will help me calm nerves in a heated moment fairly easily? i wanna be a good daughter so bad :(

You're not alone in struggling with anger and outbursts. Many people face similar challenges, and it's wonderful that you're acknowledging your concerns and seeking help. First, let's address your fears. It's understandable to be worried about potentially hurting others, but it's crucial to recognize that you're not a bad person for having a lapse. You're taking steps to improve, and that's a huge step forward.

Regarding your apology to your mom, I don't think it's essential to wait for substantial improvement before apologizing. Acknowledge what happened, express your remorse, and commit to working on your triggers. This shows that you're taking responsibility and are willing to grow.

To calm nerves in heated moments, try the following:

1. Take a 5-10 second pause before reacting. Breathe deeply, count to 10, or step away momentarily.
2. Identify and label your emotions. Recognize if you're feeling anxious, frustrated, or overwhelmed.
3. Use the "30-30-30" technique: 30 seconds of conscious breathing, 30 seconds of self-compassion, and 30 seconds of renewed focus on the situation.
4. Practice mindfulness exercises, such as progressive muscle relaxation, visualization, or guided meditations.
5. Cultivate empathy and understanding by putting yourself in others' shoes.

Remember, it's a process to develop new strategies and habits. Be patient, kind, and understanding towards yourself as you work through this.

Remember, your agency lies in taking responsible actions within your control. Focus on what you can control and adapt to the situation accordingly.

Reddit Post: I feel like all I can do is just bash my head against the wall and pray something changes. Mostly metaphorically, a little bit literally. I've tried pouring my heart and soul into figuring things out but no matter how much I debunk it feels like there's always more shit that could come out. I feel like the only 'right' thing to do is ignore it and pretend I'm okay because anything else would be making things worse for the rest of my family. I know that she cares about me but I feel so fucking helpless. I hope full approval comes soon so that might convince her but I don't know how long that will be. I feel depressed and miserable. Covid itself was bearable enough but my own mom being lied to and deceived with this shit makes me wish I didn't have to live through this. If I could've spent two years in a coma and missed all of this I'd probably be happier overall. I don't know what I could say or what to do to get her to understand. I feel like I'm breaking down.
appraisal_dimension_aim: To guide the narrator over their perception of their ability to control what was happening in the situation.
constitution: You can tell the narrator whether the situation is within their control (based on your (in third-person view) judgment). Guide the narrator on how to control the situation specifically: they can face it directly and find a solution, seek help from others (close friends, family, or professionals), or take a mental break and then re-evaluate the situation, whether it calls for their action (intervention) or not.
standards:
• A good response should tell the narrator whether the situation is within their control (based on your (in third-person view) judgment).

I understand your frustration and helplessness in this situation. It's essential to separate what you can control from what you can't. You're not responsible for your mom's decisions or the misinformation she's receiving. Your role is to provide emotional support and guidance, not dictating what she should do.

Rather than focusing on what you can't change, concentrate on what you can influence. Have open and honest conversations with your mom about your concerns, using "I" statements to express your feelings and thoughts. Avoid being confrontational or accusatory. Listen actively to her perspective, and acknowledge any valid points she makes.

It's also crucial to prioritize your own well-being. Allow yourself to feel your emotions, but don't let them consume you. Make time for self-care, engaging in activities that bring you joy and help you relax. Consider seeking support from a therapist or trusted family friend who can offer guidance and empathy.

Remember, you can't change your mom's decisions, but you can change how you respond to the situation. By focusing on what you can control and taking care of yourself, you'll be better equipped to navigate this challenging time.

intermediate_output_dim_1:
It's understandable to feel overwhelmed and uncertain about the future. However, let's break down the situation into manageable parts.

For things outside of your control, such as the pandemic, it's important to recognize that you're not responsible for the outcome. Instead of worrying about it, focus on what you can control, like your own life and well-being. Prioritize self-care, stay connected with loved ones, and find ways to stay positive and engaged.

For aspects of your daily routine, such as taking classes online or working from home, try to find the silver lining. For example, you may have more flexibility and autonomy, which can be beneficial in its own right. Look for ways to make these arrangements work for you, such as creating a dedicated workspace or setting regular schedules.

Finally, take a step back and re-evaluate your feeling of purpose. What are your values and goals? What activities bring you joy and fulfillment? Focus on making progress towards your goals, no matter how small, and celebrate your achievements along the way. Remember that it's okay to not have it all figured out, and it's never too late to make changes that align with your values and aspirations.

Remember to be patient and kind to yourself as you navigate this challenging time.

Reddit Post: This lockdown has gone on forever. From November 2020 until May 2021, restaurants were take-out only in Munich and we could only meet one person from another household. They are now finally open both inside and outside, but clubs and bars are still closed, we can only meet up to 10 friends privately, and we have to wear an FFP2 mask inside (stores, public transport) and walking around a Biergarten (which have 1/3 of tables closed still). Now we are approaching herd immunity levels finally, but there is no talk about when restrictions will finally be removed at all. The news focuses on spreading fear about the Delta variant constantly, and many people are expecting another lockdown in fall/winter despite vaccinations. Vaccinations are humanity's only hope to fight back against this virus, and if these don't work against some variants (even though all evidence so far says they do work), then there's nothing we can do. The notion of creating another lockdown to wait for a better vaccine is absolutely ridiculous because humans will never beat nature in this race. The best chance we have is to vaccinate as much as possible with what we have and take some risks again by opening up. I don't think I can mentally survive another lockdown, and if it happens I feel like I need to get out of Germany. I feel like it's hard to talk to people anymore. Most of the time when I see someone I know, I try to avoid talking to them because it's easier not to. I feel like I've become so negative that I don't want to share my thoughts with people because I will bring them down, and I already feel like I pushed some people away by doing this. I emailed multiple psychiatrists, but only one answered me and had one short appointment, and told me I should continue looking because he doesn't have time for new patients. I spend most of my time trying to get the motivation to work but failing, and looking at vaccination percentages and restrictions around the world hoping to see them improve and thinking about where else can be better than here.
appraisal_dimension_aim: To guide the narrator over their perception of their ability to control what was happening in the situation.
constitution: You can tell the narrator whether the situation is within their control (based on your (in third-person view) judgment). Guide the narrator on how to control the situation specifically: they can face it directly and find a solution, seek help from others (close friends, family, or professionals), or take a mental break and then re-evaluate the situation, whether it calls for their action (intervention) or not.
standards:
• A good response should tell the narrator whether the situation is within their control (based on your (in third-person view) judgment).
•  A good response should guide the narrator on how to control the situation specifically: they can face it directly and find a solution, seek help from others (close friends, family, or professionals), or take a mental break and then re-evaluate the situation, whether it calls for their action (intervention) or not.

[Text] This lockdown has gone on forever. From November 2020 until May 2021, restaurants were take-out only in Munich and we could only meet one person from another household. They are now finally open both inside and outside, but clubs and bars are still closed, we can only meet up to 10 friends privately, and we have to wear an FFP2 mask inside (stores, public transport) and walking around a Biergarten (which have 1/3 of tables closed still). Now we are approaching herd immunity levels finally, but there is no talk about when restrictions will finally be removed at all. The news focuses on spreading fear about the Delta variant constantly, and many people are expecting another lockdown in fall/winter despite vaccinations. Vaccinations are humanity's only hope to fight back against this virus, and if these don't work against some variants (even though all evidence so far says they do work), then there's nothing we can do. The best chance we have is to vaccinate as much as possible with what we have and take some risks again by opening up. I don't think I can mentally survive another lockdown, and if it happens I feel like I need to get out of Germany. I feel like it's hard to talk to people anymore. Most of the time when I see someone I know, I try to avoid talking to them because it's easier not to. I feel like I've become so negative that I don't want to share my thoughts with people because I will bring them down, and I already feel like I pushed some people away by doing this. However, if the person is doing something wrong/inappropriate and not feeling any responsibility or it (low responsibility), you should kindly but objectively encourage them to re-appraise the situation (or maybe think in the other person’s perspective) and consider what they could be responsible for, and change the situation. Lastly, practice self-compassion. Acknowledge that it's okay to make mistakes and that you're doing the best you can. Treat yourself with kindness, just as you would a close friend in a similar situation.

Remember, you're not alone, and we're all working to build control and confidence in our lives.
